Award.AwardTitle: EarthCube Building Blocks: Collaborative Proposal: That dot is a world! Drilling down from a statistics scatterplot to pre-populated case Notebooks.
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will develop and utilize capabilities for its scientists to "drill down" into abstract statistics about the flows of the atmosphere and ocean, to build a library of Notebooks with clear views of the actual weather systems (in the atmospheric part of the work) or Gulf of Mexico ocean eddies (in the ocean part of the work). The researchers will build this software, DRILSDOWN, using popular and powerful open-source software components that already exist, so it should be very generally applicable and have a long future. The power at the heart of the DRILSDOWN software will be the Integrated Data Viewer. The front end will consist of Jupyter Notebooks, a very popular new approach for literate computing and reproducibility of science. Literate computing allows a human-readable, meaningful, openly published document to have embedded computer-executable codes that can be repeated by anyone to replicate the results. The code can be adjusted if a user wants to see how analysis choices translate into outcomes. The involvement of scientists and a postdoc and and students will ensure the product development is useful to real research activities, while the collaboration with professional software developers (and the use of popular existing components) will ensure that it is robust and flexible enough to serve other use cases, including researchers in other areas of geoscience.

The project will develop and utilize new software called DRILSDOWN to facilitate the linking of statistics to instances, a key step in the science of complex systems. In order to guide and stress test the software development, the team will perform novel atmospheric and oceanic science newly enabled by DRILSDOWN. In the atmosphere, they will study some distinct but related published measures of high-impact flow events variously classified as Rossby wave breaking (or potential vorticity filamentation) in the upper troposphere, or as poleward water vapor transports in the lower troposphere. Three-dimensional case studies will show the relationship between these low- and high-altitude descriptions, based on statistics of each measure which will allow us to select cases with high-low, low-high, and high-high measures. How do these different measures perform at characterizing these high impact events, and how might they be reconciled and perhaps optimized? In the ocean, similar activity will be to examine statistical characterizations of eddy shedding from the Loop Current in the Gulf of Mexico, an important current system for oil spills, hurricanes, fisheries, and other hazards and interests. Full-detail case studies of marginal cases (shedding/ non-shedding) will inform fundamental science understanding of the shedding process, as well as helping to improve the algorithms for objectively measuring it, so that large ensembles of possible ocean flow scenarios can be more effectively and rapidly screened, with realistic uncertainty quantification, for instance in the event of an incident requiring ocean forecasts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project assembled a two-institution team, combining expertiese in software development (from Unidata including a key former staff member) and geo-fluid dynamics (atmospheric and oceanic sciences). Our goal was to make it easer for investigators to interpret their statistical analyses of big data sets describing these turbulent fluids, by "drilling down" into immersive, interactive visualizations of detailed case studies that are the raw material entering those statistical analysis algorithms. These case studies are rich with details, easily appreciated by the human eye and mind and hand with interactive visualization tools, yet are often algorithmically compressed without a glance into mere "data points", the "dots" mentioned in the project title. 

The project's software work updated and improved Unidata's IDV (a sophisticated data integration and visualization application) in various ways, and built connectors that link it with the popular newer Jupyter Notebook framework (a platform for reader-oriented or "literate" computing). A unified digital object called a Case Study, comprising an IDV data+code bundle plus a Jupyter notebook exposition of its contents, was defined within the closely IDV-allied repository software called RAMADDA. Scripting capabilities allow users to take one hand-crafted template Case Study, plus a list of desired time-and-location definitions of "cases", and easily create an ensemble of Case Studies in a RAMADDA repository, ready for human perusal, deeper interrogation, and capture of additional case-specific details through interactive eye-mind-hand effort. 

The project's science efforts (atmospheric plus oceanographic) were aimed at demonstrating the utility and value of the system, through the study of phenomena whose knowledge frontier involves the seeing and physical interpretaiton of 3D space-time patterns. 

In the atmosphere, these were our top use cases: 

1. We examined the vertical transport of horizontal wind momentum in cloudy convective updrafts (thunderstorms and storm complexes), in unprecedently high-resolution simulation data. This term in the equations for weather dynamics is kknown to be important, but mysterious in how it plays out: storms have a lot of freedom to do this in different ways, and there are few ways to anticipate or constrain it. Big data from high-resolution simulations serves as "artificial imagination" about this process's mysterious myriad pattern-dependent impacts. Our ensemble of case studies for big positive and negative cases revealed an unexpected surprise! In an important class of cases (large positive energy flux from smaller to larger scales), where most theory and past literature led us to expect straight quasi-two-dimensional squall lines as the underlying pattern, we found instead swirling cyclones with updrafts concentrated in certain sectors. After months of doubt about possible software bugs, we suddenly realized this result makes sense, and in fact is unsurprising. (It now even feels obvious!)

2. We created ensembles of case studies of heavy tropical rainfall events, and especially of the new phenomenon of synoptic-scale (1000s of km) "vapor-bergs" in the mostly-dry skies of the equatorial Indian Ocean, peculiar cousins of the "atmospheric river" phenomenon much discussed in the subtropics and middle latitudes. These 'bergs can last surprisingly long (days to weeks), shaping where it rains and where it doesn't. They are a form of "storm" that is little recognized, since they are not really features of the wind field, but rather their identity is based on water vapor concentration. They tend to drift very slowly, and when they hit the East African or Southwest Asian coasts they bring consequential rains. Time averaged geographical maps blur out these meandering features, so case studies are the only way to fully appreciate their dynamics. 

In the ocean, our main use case was the breaking or "shedding" of an eddy in the Loop Current of the Gulf of Mexico (GOM). This current is a branch of the basin-scale Gulf Stream that enters the GOM, turns around, and exits past Florida back into the main Atlantic. Sometimes, this hairpin turn in the current pinches off as eddy for a few months. This flow configuration (hairpin vs. pinched-off eddy) is very conseqential for the fate of oil spills, for instance. Why and how exactly does the hairpin pinch off? An ensemble of case studies shows the diversity of situations, although in this case since the flow is very geographically confined, the statistical approach in rigid latitude-longitude coordinates can proceed better without visual, spatial insight: the time averaged flow is not completely a meaningless blur, and maps of simple standard deviations and other statistical quantities are illuminating.  For these reasons, case-study visualizations proved less transformative and valuable. Still, this use case helped us iron out software kinks, like those arising from the upside-down coordinate system of oceanograpy.
